did.unittitle: William A. Speck collection of Goetheana : manuscripts

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection, a part of the William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana, consists of correspondence, documents, playscripts, and other writings by or relating to Goethe and his work. The major strength of the manuscript collection is its documentation of Goethe's literary reception in England and America in the nineteenth century. There are 25 letters and manuscripts in Goethe's hand, and several Faust-related items. Authors represented prominently besides Goethe include Thomas Carlyle, Frank Claudy, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, the Faust collector Georg Ehrhardt, Walther Wolfgang von Goethe, August Heinrich Hoffmann von Fallersleben, University of Illinois professor Julius Goebel, Anna Jameson, Johann Caspar Lavater, Friederich von Müller, Henry Crabb Robinson, Friedrich Schiller, Carl Frederick Schreiber, Horatio Robinson Storer, Bayard Taylor, Marie (Hansen) Taylor, Karl August Ludwig Philipp Varnhagen von Ense, and Albert Wünsch.
did.physdesc: Other Storage Formats: 41 Bound Volumes, Oversize

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in German; some letters in English.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of William A. Speck, 1913, and augmented by several other gifts and purchases.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: Manuscripts is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana. Yale Collection of German Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced from a previously existing card set in the Manuscript Catalog, or from anther inventory. All pertinent bibliographical information has been retained. "Speck numbers" formerly used to classify material in this collection have been replaced by standard box and folder references. This finding aid is updated periodically to account for new materials that have been added to the collection. The date of the most recent update is noted on the title page. For information on material that may have been acquired for the collection since the last update, please consult the Public Service Desk.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Printed works from the Speck Collection are cataloged separately. Two groups of manuscript material, which traditionally have been considered part of the Speck manuscript collection, also are cataloged separately: the William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana: Music (YCGL MSS 9), and the papers of Alice Raphael, Goethe translator, author, and a personal friend of William Speck.

bioghist.head: WILLIAM A. SPECK (1864-1928) and THE SPECK COLLECTION OF GOETHEANA
bioghist.p: The son of German immigrants, William A. Speck began life in New York City in 1864. His father, Otto Speck, owned an apothecary shop, first in the City, then in Haverstraw, New York, a small community on the Hudson. As a boy, Speck attended Hoboken Academy, a school run largely by Germans, and afterwards earned a degree in chemistry from the Pharmaceutical College of the City of New York. For the next thirty years, Speck conscientiously worked as a druggist in the family business, despite the fact that his real interest lay elsewhere.

Life as a Haverstraw pharmacist allowed Speck ample time to pursue his true passion: Goethe. The New York City antiquarian bookshops were only a day's trip away, and Speck was able to make two European journeys during these years. The destination was, of course, Weimar, where Speck went from door to door, up and down the streets, looking for Goethe relics, buying pictures from inn-keepers, and often gaining access to private collections.

After more than two decades of collecting, Speck saw that his books belonged in an academic setting. Personal ties suggested Columbia as the recipient of the collection; but it was Yale, having heard of the marvelous Goethe museum on the banks of the Hudson, that sent a delegation to visit Speck in 1912. In March, 1913, the Yale Corporation announced that the Goethe Collection, which then numbered about 6,000 items, had been deposited in New Haven, and that Speck had been appointed its curator.

Between the time of Speck's appointment and his death in 1928, the Collection, benefitting from University support, trebled in size. While World War I cut off the source of acquisitions for a time, the 1920s saw the purchase of two major private collections, as well as a steady stream of smaller purchases from dealers around the world. During the last years of his life, Speck was appointed lecturer in the Yale Graduate School, where he offered a course called "Goethe's Personality and Personal Appearance." Publishing relatively little, Speck devoted himself instead to assiduous collecting, firm in his belief that Goethe was "one of the corner-stones ... of our moral world."

The William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana, now the largest Goethe collection outside Germany, contains over 10,000 printed volumes and as many pamphlets, scores, programs, broadsides, prints, art works, and Goethe-related ephemera, as well as the extensive holdings of literary manuscripts, which are described in depth in this finding aid, and of manuscript music, listed and classified separately as YCGL MSS 9.
For a fuller description of the contents and collecting history of the Speck Collection, consult the Guide to the Beinecke collections (New Haven, 1974 and 1994).

Related manuscript sources in the Yale Collection of German Literature include the papers of Karl Gottfried Theodor Winkler (Theodor Hell), Dresden theater director and journalist, who corresponded with many literary figures of Goethe's time. The George Eliot Papers in the Beinecke Library's General Collection of Rare Books and Manuscripts contain much material by and relating to Goethe's biographer George Henry Lewes; some of this material was originally part of the Speck Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The major strength of the Speck Collection is its documentation of Goethe's literary reception in England and America in the nineteenth century. The literary manuscript component of the Collection, listed in detail in this finding aid, includes correspondence, documents, playscripts, and other writings. Among the better-known items to be mentioned in this connection are the full draft of Bayard Taylor's translation of Faust (folder 716), translations by George Borrow (folders 225-227), and John Greenleaf Whittier's manuscript for his translation of the poem "Erlkoenig" (folder 249). Translations, criticism, and correspondence about theater productions and the publication of Goethe's works, especially in Great Britain, include letters and manuscripts by such figures as Sarah Austin, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, Margaret Fuller, Richard Graves, Anna Jameson, Charles Kean, and Edward George Bulwer-Lytton.

The manuscripts are arranged alphabetically by author or by title, if the author is unknown. Authors represented prominently include Goethe himself, Thomas Carlyle, Frank Claudy, the Faust collector Georg Ehrhardt, Walther Wolfgang von Goethe, August Heinrich Hoffmann von Fallersleben, University of Illinois professor Julius Goebel, Anna Jameson, Johann Caspar Lavater, Friedrich von Mueller, Henry Crabb Robinson, Friedrich Schiller, Carl Frederick Schreiber, Horatio Robinson Storer, Bayard Taylor, Marie (Hansen) Taylor, Karl August Ludwig Philipp Varnhagen von Ense, and Albert Wuensch. The Rilke manuscripts, chiefly letters to F. A. Huenich (folder 565) and Clotilde Sacharoff (folders 567-568), came into the collection by historical accident and are unrelated to Goethe.

Despite his persistence and the financial resources provided by Yale, Speck could not gather a large number of Goethe autographs, which were already in the great collections at Weimar and Frankfurt and in the Kippenberg Collection. The Speck Collection does, however, include some 25 letters and manuscripts in Goethe's hand, among them the poem "Den funfzehn englischen Freunden" (folder 254), sent in thanks to the group of British writers who, at the suggestion of Thomas Carlyle, had presented Goethe with a gold and enamel seal for his 81st birthday. Goethe's fair copy of the scene "Offene Gegend" from the second part of Faust is another treasure (folder 224). There are in addition many letters to Goethe, and letters from Goethe in secretarial hands. Among the other, related correspondence in the collection are many letters to Johann Peter Eckermann, including seven from Thomas Carlyle (folders 50-56).

The manuscript collection (both literary and music) is particularly strong in Faust-related materials, including two eighteenth-century Hoellenzwang manuscripts, bound, (folders 797-798) and a number of late nineteenth century handwritten copies of Faust puppet plays. There are also several manuscripts by the Swiss theologian Johann Kaspar Lavater, a branch of whose family migrated to Connecticut and became Yale benefactors.

did.unittitle: AMs, 4 p. l., 103 l. front. (port.) ; 26 x 21 cm. A parody adaptation of Goethe's Faust in verse; without music; stage directions indicate popular tunes, to which some of the poems are to be sung, accompanied by band or orchestra. Title in red and black calligraphy; the word "Faust" embellished with human figures representing characters in the play; names of characters and stage directions in red, all within red line borders. The frontispiece is a photograph of the author, with his signature below. Bound in half leather. With: Song, "Come let us be jovial," by H. A. B., 3 l. following l. 103. Within black borders.

The printed pages 141-208, representing nearly all of section II, chapter 1 of Eschenburg's Handbuch der klassischen Literatur, possibly of the edition pub. at Berlin in 1783, are interleaved; they bear ms. corrections and additions for a later edition; printed p. 225-240 of the 6th ed. of 1816, are laid in at end. One half page preceding p. 143, one following p. 146 of the printed ed., and 4 p. at end with title "Kurze Geschichte Griechenlandes" are in an unidentified hand. Following p. 140 of the notes is the poem "Lied der Sappho, übers. von Weisse." With autographed armorial bookplate of Arnold W. Eschenburg. Gift of Carl F. Schreiber.
ESENBECK, C. G. NEES VON (CHRISTIAN GOTTFRIED DANIEL)

AMs, 192 p., 1 l. illus. (part col.) ; 33 x 29 cm. Size of pages varies from 31 x 24 cm. to 33 x 29 cm. did.unittitle: Faust; a tragedy, by J. Wolfgang von Goethe. n.d.

AMs, 3 v. (5-112 p. ; [112] p.; [85] p.) ; 23 cm. First part of Goethe's "Faust" translated into English verse by Jonathan Birch. Some pages are blank. With copious corrections by the author, many in pencil; a few text variants on slips inserted. At end of each, vol. notes, various drafts of poems, etc. Interleaved with a copy of Faust, eine Tragödie, von Goethe. Neue Aufl. Stuttgart und Tübingen: J. G. Cotta, 1831. The translation of Pt. I was first pub. London: Black and Armstrong; Leipzig: F. A. Brockhaus, 1839.
Faust; a tragedy in two parts by J. Wolfgang von Goethe. n.d.

AMs, 80, 8 p., 78 l. ; 31 cm. Second part of Goethe's "Faust" translated into English verse by Jonathan Birch. Incomplete draft. In portfolio. First 80 p. bound in in paper covers, 8 p. and 78 l. bound separately, its covers lost. Some of the 78 l. have text in pencil or ink on verso, chiefly variants. Translation of pt. II, act I, scene Lustgarten, line 6003 to act 4, scene Auf dem Vorgebirg, line 10454; with ms. correction in ink or pencil. On inside front cover, p. 79-80 first count, and inside back cover are notes in pencil or ink, and English and German versions of a poem, beginning: Come dearest, come [Komm, Liebchen, komm]. On leaf attached at front a short note on the translation, dated October 1843. The translation of pt. II was first pub. London: F.A. Brockhaus, 1843. In portfolio with this are 14 mounted clippings from English newspapers containing reviews of Birch's and other translations of Goethe's Faust, and some items of general contents; the clippings had been mounted on pages of the ms. over the text.
But shall a poodle also mumble?

273, 3 p., 1 l., incl. music ; 20 cm. Manuscript copy in an unidentified calligraphic hand. Moulds, March 1785. With music: p.238-240. "The Force of Love being a Sequel to the Sorrows of Werter, Composed by John Moulds ... March 1785" [with music]: p.271-273. Bookplate of Robert Watts; crest of Sir Thomas Phillips, of Middle Hill, stencilled on fly-leaf.

284 p. ; 26 x 21 cm. Taskin's Russian translation in blank verse of Goethe's Torquato Tasso. Transliterated title: Torkvato Tasso. Calligraphic hand, evidently of a professional copyist; the signature to the dedication, however, appears to be in the translator's own hand. With dedication to "Your Imperial Highness," presumably Grand Duke Alexander, subsequently Emperor Alexander III. Translator states in the dedication that he is a native of Siberia.

1 l. ; 11 x 18 cm., mounted to 29 x 36 cm. Autograph ms., signed, Goethe. Mounted on black edged pink mat, decorated with birds and flowers; the decoration was done by Alwine Frommann. The autograph was written for the Grandduchess Maria Pavlovna; she in turn gave it to her daughter Augusta, who in 1861 became Queen of Prussia and ten years later the first Empress of Germany. With autograph note, signed, from Augusta to Hofbibliothekar Samuel Heinrich Spiker, on his sixtieth birthday, December 24, 1846, on letter paper with lace border, bearing the Hohenzollern crest.
You are the merriest undone man in Europe, Weimar

did.unittitle: 7 LS : Weimar, to Johann Friedrich Unger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
11 p. ; various sizes
Letters dated: Jan. 30, 1798; Aug. 5,
1799; Nov. 4, 1799; Mar. 3, 1800;
Apr. 2, 1800; Apr. 10, 1800 and Jun.
8, 1803.
All in the handwriting of Goethe's
secretary Ludwig Geist.
The first six letters concern the
publication of Goethe's Neue
Schriften, Berlin, J.F. Unger, 1792-
1800, 7 vols. The last is a letter of
thanks for Unger's gift of a copy of
Chr. E. von Kleists Sämtliche Werke.
All printed in Weimar Ausgabe.
With: Two letters from Bernhard Suphan
to Prof. K. Budde in Bonn, dated May
27, 1888 and July 11, 1888.

did.unittitle: Autograph receipt, signed, to James Dodsley

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 p. ; 19 x 9 cm.
Official impressed revenue seal.
Mounted.
With ms. note "N.B. Mr. Graves
afterwards rec'd as much more as made
it 200£." - Prof. Ian A. Gordon of
University of New Zealand says, this
endorsement is in the handwriting of
Bishop Thomas Percy.
Receipt for forty pounds in full for
the copyright of "The Sorrows of
Werter."
For explanation of the circumstances
concerning this receipt, see William
A. Speck's article "Revealing two
secrets of the Sorrowful Werter" in
The Literary digest international
book review, May, 1926; also Charles
J. Hill, "The first English
translation of Werther," in Modern
Language notes, 1932, v. 45.

did.unittitle: 407 p. ; 17 x 16 - 21 x 17 cm. Bound volume in case. In Latin; a few with German postscripts. Preceded by a German poem by Johann Friedrich Hiepe (or Hilpe), a student, 1700, at the occasion of a special event at the school; a prayer in German, at the dedication of a church, unsigned, undated; Oratio congratulatoria, in German verse, by B.C. Daniel, 1694, on the birthday of the Prince of Schwartzburg; and several speeches, etc. in Latin. Letter no. 67, Aug. 15, 1670, from J. Hoffmann to Joh. Barth. Oberländer, in Latin. A few letters are without addresses. Hoffmann was rector at the school in Frankenhausen, Saxony, from 1681 to 1718. Besides treatises on theology, philosophy, history, and geography, he wrote Latin hymns, German songs, and a few school plays. Transcriptions of the German text are with the volume.

did.unittitle: ALS : Bath, to Elizabeth Barrett Browning

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
3 p. ; 11 x 18 cm., with envelope.
Both letter and envelope with black
border.
Landor excuses his delay in replying
for the reason: "I could not, by
any exertion of ingenuity, decipher
your signature. Do you write your
name in such a manner, that nobody
may attempt forgery? ... I remember
to have red[!], fifty years ago,
Theseus, a Monodrama by Stolberg.
Of course I mean in the translation.
It is the only Greek modern thing I
ever saw. Goethe is so little
hellenic that he represents
Iphegenia (a girl of 12 or 13)
arguing on the injustice done to
the sex in various ways. His
tragedy is insufferably dull."

Lord Chatam, oder Pitts Büste Commentiert, für Heinrich Lips. n.d.

AMs, signed, 38 p. diagrs., 4 mounted ports. ; 37 cm., with brown board covers. Date on t.p.: Kloten, Sonntags, den 18. October 1789; on p. [30]: Zürich, Dienstags den 13. Jenner. 1789. Signed on t.p. and p.[30]. Four portraits, original pen drawings, mounted and within green and black borders, laid in at end. This essay has never been printed. - Mr. von Faber's old catalogue card.
Vermischte physiognomische Regeln. Manuscript für Freünde, mit einigen characterischen Linien. Erstes Hundert. Zum Bessten der Armen . 1789

AMs, 103 loose leaves ; 21 x 13 cm., in box ; 23 x 16 cm. Leaf 51 misnumbered 57. Calligraphic writing within black and pink borders; many leaves have line drawings of facial features, illustrative of the text. Vignette with bust of Lavater, by J. Merz, mount. on inside front cover of box. Published in Hand-Bibliothek für Freünde [Zurich] 1793, v.1.

70 drawings in 3 boxes ; 23 x 16 cm. The boxes have labels on inside front cover, numbered 1-3. Original pen and ink drawings of faces, showing features in progressive stages from the crude to the refined; with inscriptions in Lavater's hand. These sketches were not used in Lavater's Physiognomische Fragmente. Box 1, with title "Vermischtes" on spine, contains 25 drawings numbered 1-18; 2, 4-9. The faces, mostly on yellow background within black circle, surrounded by a square ornamental frame; ms. inscription below circle; the whole mounted on strong paper. Box 2, with title "Stufen" on spine, contains 27 drawings numbered 1-8; 18-25; 1-10, 25. The first 2 groups as in box 1, in the 3d group the drawings are within black circle, the inscriptions on labels with engraved border; both mounted on boards covered on recto with blue paper; drawing 15 of the 3d group (Goethe's portrait?), in the same state, is in color and has no inscription. Box 3, with title "Stufen" on spine, contains 18 items: 6 unnumb.; no. 1-4, 1-6. The 6 unnumb. drawings within gold, black and pale green border mounted on boards; nos. 1-4 within black circles surrounded by blue, mounted on light green boards nos.1-6, each containing a drawing of a man in full figure in an attitude of supplication against a round pale green background, which is surrounded by blue, all within black frame and mounted on boards; also 1 mounted engraved plate (18 x 12 cm.) and 1 colored drawing of a peasant woman (14 x 10 cm.); all items bear inscriptions.

did.unittitle: AMs, 366 p. ; 27 x 21 cm. Green half-leather binding. "Wilhelm Hof" on t.p. crossed off, "Franz Berthold," another pseudonym used by the author, pencilled below. The author was a friend of Tieck. She sent the ms. to Rotteck under the name of W. Hof; it was thought to be lost and has never been published or described. - Note on Mr. von Faber's old catalogue card. Cf. Edith Gilmore, Masaniello in German literature; Thesis, Ph.D., Yale University, 1950.
Saul, Trauerspiel in fünf Aufzügen. n.d.

AMs, 74 unnumb. l. ; 27 x 20 cm. Red half-leather binding. This work was probably begun in 1828, reworked in 1829/30 and revised again in 1831. "Einige Szenen aus dem noch ungedruckten Trauerspiel von Franz Berthold [Saul]," consisting of the concluding passages of the fourth and the beginning of the fifth act, were printed in "Ost und West; Blätter für Kunst, Literatur und geselliges Leben," ed. by R. Glaser, Prague, 2. Jahrg., 1838, no. 23, 24, 26, 27. Four complete manuscripts are in Königl. Bibliothek Berlin. Cf. Johannes Wetzel: Adelheid Reinbold. Diss. Leipzig, 1911, p. 17, 27 and footnotes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 p. l., 143, 263-305 l. (549- 29-65
l. of text variants) ; 33 cm.
One leaf, marked L 1, inserted after
l. 80.
The leaves 300-305 are re-marked 35-
39a, respectively.
The text variants are for the German
Faust book (1587), the English
Faust book (1592), Marlowe's Dr.
Faustus (1604), and the English
ballad (Roxburghe Collection).
Parts of this work were pub. as the
author's Ph.D. thesis, University of
Munich, 1906, and in his Studies in
English Faust literature I. The
English Wagner book of 1594, in the
series: Literarhistorische
Forschungen, Heft 35, 1907.

and hopes to publish both parts
together - they came out in 1959.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

2 p. ; 26 x 22 cm., with address.

the still remaining copies of the
piano score of his Oratorio; he
cannot agree to the price set by
Breitkopf & Härtel for 2 manuscripts
offered them for sale, but he is
willing to write a song for their
album by the middle of September;
requests a corrected proof of his
Oratorio.

Autograph poem, signed, 1 p. ;
22 x 14 cm.
Signed: B. T.
Without title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
AMs, 24 p. ; various sizes.
Several poems in Mrs. Taylor's hand,
and one composed by her, Dec. 20,
1872.
Contents: Da die Gläser sind noch
nicht leer; Kennst du das Land, wo
schönste Braten blühen (parody of
Goethe's "An Mignon"); Abschiedslied;
Edles Paar, ihr habt vom tiefen
Kelch des Lebens; Lieblich, sanft
und milde; Ich wandl' auf deiner
Pfad, Natur!; Nachdem der
Neujahrstag war gekommen; Das Wetter
(by Marie Taylor); Wohngedicht; Ich
habe unausstehlichen Durst; Wer
leidet an einem bösen Husten; Die
durst'ge Erde trinkt den Regen;
Leidevoll, kreidevoll (parody of
Goethe's "Freudvoll und leidvoll");
Der Versuch deutsche Gedichte; Das
Lied vom schläfrigen Manne; Gelobet
sei Schlaf!; Er legt sich auf's Heu;
Die Hinterbliebenen traurig; Ich
sitze in der Laube; An die liebe,
gute Tante; Vom Nordkay.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph poem, 1 p. ; 27 x 21 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:

25 x 20 cm.

Printed in the "Evening Post," "New
York Tribune," "New York Herald,"
and "The World" on August 30, 1875;
also in B. Taylor's Home pastorals,
ballads and lyrics, 1875.
A facsimile appeared as Facsimile and
reproductions of unique or rare
items from the William A. Speck
Collection of Goetheana, 1918, no. 4.

"New Yorker Staatszeitung" published
a German translation by Carl Theodor
Erben.

1) Die verwandelten Weiber; oder, Der

AMs, signed, 87 p. ; 21 x 17 cm.
Title from label on cover.
Signed: Albert Wünsch. Orderan den
13ten Juli 1882.
Based on Christian Felix Weisse's opera
of the same title, which was set to
music by Johann Adam Hiller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
2) Der Geiger und sein Liebchen, n.d.
AMs, 3 p. ; 21 x 17 cm.
Transcriber unknown.
Poem apparently spoken to accompany a
pantomime.
Not in Albert Wünsch's handwriting.
Incomplete? The rhyme would indicate
that a portion is wanting between
p.[2] and [3].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
3) Hoffnung, Liebe, Glaube, n.d.
AMs, 3 p. ; 21 x 17 cm.
Transcriber unknown.
Divided in 1.-3. Bild: 1. Hoffnung;
2. Liebe; 3. Hoffnung, Glaube, Liebe.
Poem in five verses.
In the same handwriting as that of the
second version of Goethe's Der
Fischer, and of the poem "Nach meiner
Meinung ganz egal", in the same
volume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
4) Jetzt geths[!] los! 48, n.d.
AMs, 5 p. ; 21 x 17 cm.
Transcriber unknown.
A poem in four verses.
"48" in title may mean "1848".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
5) Lied und Liebe. (Lebendes Bild 2
Tableaux), n.d.
AMs, 3 p. ; 21 x 17 cm.
Transcriber unknown.
A poem in nine verses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
6) Nach meiner Meinung ganz egal, n.d.
AMs, 5 p. ; 21 x 17 cm.
Transcriber unknown.
A poem in six verses; the first in a
different handwriting from the rest,
which is that of the transcriber of
the second version of Goethe's Der
Fischer, in the same volume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
7) Die Wacht am Rhein Rhein.
(Lebentes[!] Bild in 2 Tablaux),
Lengefeld, 1884 Jun 17.
AMs, 2 p. ; 21 x 17 cm.
Transcriber unknown.
First line: Ein einsam Bild auf hoher
Warte.
Not M. Schneckenburger's famous poem
(Es braust ein Ruf wie Donnerhall).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
8) Müller, Karl. Des Fischers letzter
Fang, n.d.
AMs, signed, 4 p. ; 21 x 17 cm.
Holograph copy of Goethe's Poem "Der
Fischer."
In the same handwriting as "Der Geiger
und sein Liebchen" in the same
volume.
Transcription full of errors and
dialect inflections; the verse before
the last is omitted and supplied, in
pencil in a different handwriting,
following Müller's signature.
Divided in 1.-2. Bild.
On slip inserted at front, in G.
Ehrhardt's handwriting: "Goethes ...
Ballade "Der Fischer" wurde von dem
Marionettentheaterbesitzer und
Spieler Apel unter der Bezeichnung
"Des Fischers letzter Fang" noch
zwischen 1880 u. 1890 nach den
Aufführungen der Puppenstücke ... als
persönliches Nachspiel (lebendes
Bild) aufgeführt."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
9) Another holograph copy, in a different
handwriting, of the same poem under
title: Des Fischers letzter Fang, n.d.
AMs, 2 p. ; 21 x 17 cm., bound
following the above.
Divided in 1.-2. Bild.

129 unnumb. l. of col. illus., with t.p. in ms. ; 21 x 14 cm. The illustrations consist of a blue flower, playing card (seven of spades), cabbalistic symbols, devil's head and a coat-of-arms repeated over and over in this order. Through cutting edges of leaves, six divisions are formed which enable the user to find readily the same picture. Formerly owned by Carl Engel. - Ehrhardt's catalogue note no. 577.
